cinder/backup/drivers/ceph.py.message: Given your tests for this are >0, why have this set to -1 and not 0?

> Is that actually documented? If not it should be, at least, mentioned here

Would a rewording be of the help string to e.g: "Settings this to >=1 can save disk space [...]" be sufficient? 

It's simply NOT limited by default (without this code or with backup_ceph_keep_snapshots_count=-1 which is the default with the new code).

> -1: Defaults is -1 (unlimited), but 0 is also unlimited.  We should have only 1 acceptable value for unlimited.

Looking at the various config parameters available I agree with your point that cinder uses "0" to set something to "unlimited" in case of integers (https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/xena/configuration/block-storage/samples/cinder.conf.html)


But looking at the oslo.config reference for integers parameters at https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.config/latest/reference/api/oslo_config.html#oslo_config.types.Integer there actually is the 'None' value.

Looking at how other projects like e.g. Nova or Designate are using 'None':

 * https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#DEFAULT.metadata_workers
 * https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/admin/config.html#service:api.default_limit_v2

it seems a default of 'None' and then a minimum value of '1' would make the most sense here: 

 1) You either enable a functionality by setting any value but the default of 'None'.
 2) But you then limit the range to the sensible values. This rules out "0" which renders incremental backups non-functional. (Setting a e.g. a "service:api.default_limit_v2" to "0" defaults to not return any records ;-)
While I think a value of 0 for "unlimited" could cause confusion because 0 rather indicates "none", I agree on maintaining Cinder's current default value for "unlimited", which turns out to be 0.
Is that actually documented? If not it should be, at least, mentioned here
-1: Defaults is -1 (unlimited), but 0 is also unlimited.  We should have only 1 acceptable value for unlimited.
Yeah - that would work I think

-1: Previously this would not happen unless an operator had manually deleted snapshot in the Ceph cluster, in which case they are on their own, but now this can easily happen with the new config option, so we have to handle it better.

In my opinion there are 2 things that need to happen in this case:

- The backup has to be marked as not being an incremental backup in Cinder's database.  This is important in case someone is using the records to charge, it avoids creating a false chain of backups (which prevent deleting the false parent before the new backup), and it also makes it easier for user to understand why the backup is taking longer.  This is done by returning {"parent_id": None} as part of the updates dictionary of the "backup" method.  It's dirty and is part of the reason why I didn't want this new feature to be done like this, because the user doesn't get what they asked for.

- Need a new "user message" indicating that the backup will not be incremental even if it was asked to be, otherwise they could go crazy because they asked for incremental and they didn't get it. (look into cinder/messages)

To address this issue, I have added a new pre-check to see whether an incremental backup would be possible (if one was requested). If not possible, we fall back to a full backup instead and therefore do not run into this exception.
The backup will then be marked as full in the database by having no parent_id.

I also added a new user message for that case, like you suggested, though it's still WIP. It's not fully clear to me yet where exactly it will/should be displayed. Right now, I can only see it via openstack volume message list/show.
Additionally, the mapping from Detail ID to Detail message seems to not work. The new ID is always mapped to the default "unknown error". Am I missing something here?
Probably the message level should also be something different than "error".
-1: Failure to list snapshots at this point should never prevent the backup from being marked as ok.
Ack, use try/except to handle errors
nit: maybe assign this to a variable so the code in this method is a bit easier to read
-1: Failure to delete an image will prevent the driver from marking the backup as successful.

doc/source/configuration/block-storage/b.message: -1: This new feature needs a proper explanation with the problem, the solution, and the tradeoff.

-1 = unlimited (as it is until this config flag is introducted)
Keeping only "0" snapshots is not a good default as it changes the behavior and consequently causes no incremental backups to ever be created as there is no source snapshot to start from that's kept.

so really without direct support in barbican we could not transfer instance with securets.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Could you please describe the scenario in a bit more detail when a race happens causing the issue? Also it would be nice to have a (functional) test that actually reproduces the race condition.

we support add more than one host to aggerate on the dashboard and send many aggegate/{host}/add_host apis to nova_api, nova_api get the same aggregate without host at[1], and cast nova_scheduler to update_aggregates for self.host_aggregates_map, the later host will replace the former host at [2].
[1] https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/nova/+/refs/heads/master/nova/compute/api.py
[2] https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/nova/+/refs/heads/master/nova/scheduler/host_manager.py

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: recheck

nova/scheduler/host_manager.py.message:
> we support add more than one host to aggerate on the dashboard and send many
> aggegate/{host}/add_host apis to nova_api, nova_api get the same aggregate without host
> at[1], and cast nova_scheduler to update_aggregates for self.host_aggregates_map, the
> later host will replace the former host at [2].
> [1] https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/nova/+/refs/heads/master/nova/compute/api.py
> [2] https://review.opendev.org/plugins/gitiles/openstack/nova/+/refs/heads/master/nova/scheduler/host_manager.py


So you described the race as following:
* Client wants to add two hosts (host1, host2) to an aggregate. Lets assume for the current example that the aggregate has no hosts at the start.
* Clients sends two aggegate/{host}/add_host requests (req1, req2) to nova
* nova-api reads the aggregate from the DB. If the two requests are handled quickly (or in parallel) then both req1 and req2 reads the same, empty aggregate from the DB and nova-api adds host1 to the aggregate in req1 and host2 to the aggregate in req2. Then nova sends the both request to the scheduler req1(agg.hosts=[host1]) req2(agg.hosts=[host2])

With the lock you proposed to introduce the scheduler will handle req1 and req2 in sequence. 

Let's assume a sequence of req1, req2. Then
* after req1: self.host_aggregates_map = {host1: [agg]}
* then after req2 will add host2: [agg] to the map but remove agg from host1. So self.host_aggregates_map = {host2: [agg], host1: []}

So the lock you introduce here does not solve the race condition you described. 

I still suggest to provide a test case that reproduces the race first, then propose a fix.

Posting -2 to blocking merge now.

In my understanding we do not use these roles now.

The octavia package in RDO installs the policy rule file, which makes octavia to use the conventional keystone roles(admin or not) instead of the default rules implemented in code

Takashi,
This is part of the secure-RBAC work. As you mentioned, Octavia has had these roles since Pike, but TripleO had previously overrode these with the old admin-or-owner policy.
With the switch to "secure-RBAC" we are moving closer to what Octavia has had support for. In fact, the "secure-RBAC" and enable-secure-RBAC environment leverages and overrides these roles to provide the project-member, project-reader functionality.
Greg is adding these roles to keystone in Tripleo to bring alignment with the default roles in Octavia and the new "secure-RBAC" policies.
It will also simplify the tempest testing as you noted, because these keystone roles can be used in both the Octavia "advanced RBAC" and the "secure-RBAC" configurations.
The advantage for customers is if they are/have been using these roles with Octavia previously, they will now be compatible in Tripleo deployments and compatible with the "secure-RBAC" policies. If the customer does not need them, they will cause no issue in the cloud, but will make tempest testing easier (you don't have to override the role configuration in tempest.conf).
This looks legit. Is there a bug for this @gthiemonge?
W-1 I don't think we need it with the new RBAC stuff
recheck getting new CI results
recheck tripleo-ci-centos-9-scenario010-standalone blocker fix was merged
recheck tripleo-ci-centos-9-scenario010-standalone failed

The history of the advanced RBAC and more granular roles goes back to work we did with Nova based on a customer request for more granular RBAC policies. Octavia merged their implementation, nova did not. However, the current secure-RBAC proposal gets us closer to the capabilities provided by Octavia.

That said, I understand that we should limit options provided to users, but this patch is not adding a new tripleo parameter, it is just creating the roles up front.
If we don't do this, we will have to make changes to the tempest RPMs to configure role overrides specific to the Tripleo deployments. It seemed like this was the better approach as it provides Tripleo compatibility with the Octavia default roles and does not require any special handling/configuration on the behalf of users. It all "just works".

> That said, I understand that we should limit options provided to users, but this patch is not adding a new tripleo parameter, it is just creating the roles up front.

My concern is exactly about showing up multiple roles. If a operator see these roles, it's quite reasonable that he/she is puzzled by difference between reader and loadbalancer-observer. I'm pretty sure it looks quite strage to them that no instance-observer or volume-observer are created.


> If we don't do this, we will have to make changes to the tempest RPMs to configure role overrides specific to the Tripleo deployments. It seemed like this was the better approach as it provides Tripleo compatibility with the Octavia default roles and does not require any special handling/configuration on the behalf of users. It all "just works".

To run tempest without configuring roles, you can set the tht option to enable these roles. I'm not quite getting how badly it affects us to keep these optional. It might not be the very best as we are not testing the actual default in tripleo but as long as octavia-tempest-plugin covers the default keystone roles(I believe yes) then it would not cause any missing test coverage but just allows coverage beyond defaults.

I'd not block your work with tight deadline here so I'd remove -2 if this should be merged as it is. But I'd appreciate if you can give it another thought to whether this is required by default.

Hmm... I assume this is required to let octavia tempest tests pass ?

I understand Octavia has been delivering its own rules, but I'm afraid adding these rules are quite confusing for the users. Because of the policy rules installed by the package Octavia now allows keystone default roles (admin, member, reader) by default and I don't expect users would be eager to use these specific roles rather than general default ones.

IMO we better keep these roles optional at least, and consider adding an additional knob to octavia-tempest-plugin to disable its own roles as a long term solution.

Hi Michael,

Thank you for your explanation and I understand your point, as I spent some time recently to set up octavia job in puppet integration jobs. However I'd argue this is not the simplification for users, while it's simplification for development/testing.

My main concern is that providing "too many" options is quite confusing for users sometimes. It's hard to understand why the same is not provided for the other services like nova, unless you understand the historical decision made in Octavia and the other projects.

If the user has been using these octavia specific roles then this might be useful but in that case they are aware that these have not been created by default. Keeping these optional would not harm them.

So unless there is any blocker, I'd still prefer keeping this optional (like adding a parameter like OctaviaCreateRoles). If we learn enough use cases where this project specific role is required then we can turn it on at some point.

Daniel is added as a reviewer because he brought up the issue when he was trying to generate secret for opensearch with http-utils (when passlib is not installed).

The problem encountered in Zuul prevents the execution of an external program,
script. Everything that produce stdout, that later is registered as task variable,
is cleared by Zuul.
It raise an issue, when the stdout needs to be set into a variable, template, etc.
For example, user might want to encrypt a text as a base64 by using command/shell
module, then it will be registered to the task variable. Normally, the
variable in printing will be a dictionary, which contain "stdout", "stdout_lines" keys, that
later can be used in other tasks. In Zuul, it makes that field empty, which is incorrect.
I agree, that Zuul should not be able to print variables, that earlier were declared, because
it might be a securrity breach, but for the newest variables, it should allow to do it. However, user can print old variable and assign it to the new var, which can be a huge problem.
In other words, it might be difficult from Zuul CI administrator, to prevent showing sensitive data to the user. From the other side,
basic functionality that is provided by Ansible is needed.

An update to this. This code was initially adopted from ansible and I suspect the behavior you see here was also ansible behavior. However, more modern ansible appears to apply some heuristics to santize no_log values out of the variables it is returning. This is also problematic as it means collisions can be exploited to determine secret info.

I'm not sure what the right approach is here, but just letting the info through and trying to apply sanitization both seem to be insufficiently safe to me.

I am also confused about this behavior, it's just that the tasks defined in the commit message are presently not working with Zuul, while they do work with Ansible.

If I understand correctly, Ansible does censor the output later when running in verbose mode:

  # in roles/testy/tasks/main.yaml
  - name: No log shell register
    zuul_command:
      zuul_log_id: 42
      argv:
        - echo
        - secret
    register: _task
    no_log: true

  # setup zuul_command with ln -s command.py zuul/ansible/base/library/zuul_command.py

  $ ansible -v testy.yamml
  PLAY [localhost] 

  TASK [testy : No log shell register] 
  changed: [localhost] => {"censored": "the output has been hidden due to the fact that 'no_log: true' was specified for this result", "changed": true}


Though I guess we'll need to also patch the zuul_json callback to do the same for job-output.json.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Probably we need some reasoning here to convince the rest of the cores to accept it.

My view:
Pros
* no need to manually format code -> less mental load on the developer
* no need to review code formatting -> less mental load on the reviewer
* consistent style across the whole code base -> easier to read and navigate code

Cons
* when we merge this all the open reviews will go into merge conflict. It is a one time pain that can be fixed with: checkout patch, run black and commit, rebase patch, push for review
* merge conflict on backport to stable branches. Possible solutions: a) do the blackification on stable brances too b) live with the pain
* git blame will show Sean for almost everything. Solution is to add this commit to .git-blame-ignore-revs . That will work in git but we need to see if it works in other tools (gerrit, gitea) too.
* devs and reviewers need to get used to reading the new style. I think this will be easy as the new style is pretty readable. (Note, you never need to write this style, black will do it for you)

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
To give some background on user level enforcement, in nova we wanted to remove it completely and interesting it was not known things in nova itself that with policy.json rule check string operator can limit the operation at user level. This was not intend from nova at all and came up during v2->v2.1 implementation. 

But when removing it completely in newton cycle, we got feedback from operator not to break existing deployment and use case and at least keep it for a limited defined server destructive actions. This spec can give you more clarity on discussion and work done to limit the user enforcement

- https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/newton/implemented/user-id-based-policy-enforcement.html

And as long term when project hierarchy things will be there in OpenStack then we should remove the current user enforcement from each API policy and make it project  level only. But we need to keep those until we have project hierarchy concept.

In summary, we cannot extend the user enforcement in more policy and should work to remove the existing one instead.

I apologize for not being part of the discussion of this spec during this release and when it was proposed. I've certainly shared this sentiment in the past when we discussed this.

I'm really worried that we're proposing a "micro" version to encapsulate what amounts to a huge amount of change across our API. I think that in both cases of "track a single microversion" and "use a specific microversion per request" client designs, this will be painful.

If I track a single microversion with my client, then in order to get some feature in 2.92, I have to make a *lot* of change to my client before I can access that one feature. That also likely makes it hard for me to support older versions with just a microversion flag to my client.

If I instead send a specific microversion per call (say X for instance boot but Y for instance resize), then my generic resource handling code needs to allow for the possibility of these differences everywhere.

In both cases, assuming I'm trying to support more than one major version of Nova, I have to keep all that code in place for a long time anyway, and this microversion doesn't relieve me of that need.

As an alternative, could we just *add* project_id in all the places without removing tenant_id? Meaning, show both in the responses, allow both in filter queries, and show tenant_id as deprecated in the documentation? Someday we could potentially remove it in a microversion, but I'm not sure we really need to. I think the argument for making this change is that users are confused reading our documentation on how to use our API, and "ignore this deprecated thing" would be of no consequence to them and thus still achieve the goal I think. Taking this approach will be far less pain for client libraries. Yes, they might not all convert at the first sign of the deprecation notice, but that's not a huge concern. Being nice and compatible with our long-time users but also advising the new users to use the proper fields seems like the best compromise.
++ I'm happy to help with writing (or reviewing) either or both of those.

Personally, I don't think there's any reason to remove it, other than subjective purity. If and when we do, we'll just be introducing the same barrier that we would be now, which is a microversion that creates a ton of change that has to be accounted for in order to use anything past it. That said, being compatible for a good long while at least gives the opportunity for people to notice the "you should be using project not tenant" microversion and convert in a non-emergency sort of way.

Do we have a libvirt regression then? Or is this change tight to a major libvirt version? As far as I see the libvirt doc[1] still states: 
>  The value should be in range [2, 262144]

The max is in cgroups, not libvirt. So libvirt will handle 10000 just fine, pass it straight through to cgroups, and the latter will complain.

this is not a libvirt regerssion persay.

libvirt was doing a direct passthough to the underlying cgroups api so that value changed between cgroups v1 and cgroups v2

there is an libvirt/qemu bug for change in behaivor within libvirt 
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2037998
https://gitlab.com/libvirt/libvirt/-/issues/324

if you doploy the same libvirt on a differnt os or revert to croups v1 then we would not hit this issue.
Still feels like a failure in libvirt. A failure of abstracting out the hypervisor layer. As a libvirt user what I see that what worked before now stopped working. :/

OK. so this nova patch is more like a WA until (if ever) libvirt fixes issues/324. This is fine by me. But In general I don't think that nova is the right place to create a cgroups abstraction just because libvirt failed to do it. :)

I don't disagree, but I think libvirt has always lived in a weird no man's land between full hypervisor (so something like Xen or HyperV, which provider a higher level of abstraction), and thin wrapper around bare qemu+kvm, so while I agree that libvirt should fix this (and there's a libvirt issue tracking this [1]), I'm not so sure that it's outside of Nova's scope to try and mitigate this as well.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: For the upgrade impact, we (Red Hat) discussed this internally. We think upstream it's fair to ask operators who have set this value to update their flavors and resize, as we consider that they own the risk of setting a value that is so coupled to the underlying host OS.
what would be potential upgrade impact for resize/migrate? Maybe existing VMs with <10k should retain the value instead of switching it to unpredictable defaults coming from libvirt?

The bug introduced into libvirt is that it passes through "shares" as "weight", and because the range is no longer invalid, OpenStack can exhibit failure to launch machines, or failures to migrate machines. I believe this is a bug, as "shares" and "weight" are different configurations according to cgroups v1 and cgroups v2, but libvirt is treating them as if they are synonymous with no mapping.

I have been patching libvirt for the last year to work around this, by having it pass CPUShares through to systemd instead of CPUWeight, and letting systemd scale it "properly" (it maps the linear scale as proportional to the range). I had posted a patch to the libvirt developers, and they seemed to not be fans of the approach - however, it remains broken:

https://gitlab.com/libvirt/libvirt/-/issues/161

So, I'm interesting in seeing this patch, or one like it applied to OpenStack. It may not be perfect - but unless you scale it the same way systemd does with CPUShares, your attempt to scale will also be imperfect.

Technically the CPUShares or CPUWeight may not be applicable unless you oversubscribe the machines, so to some degree - even if it is wrong, it won't create breakage. However, if you have an SLA of some sort with a customer who is paying for CPU time, and you give them less time per CPU thread with larger instances because of this problem, they may not be so forgiving.

I waiting to see what the libvirt people do next. So far - my patch to libvirt has worked just fine. OpenStack continues to work, passing "shares" through, which gets passed through to systemd as "CPUShares" instead of "CPUWeight", and systemd scales it properly. So, time until the situation is disrupted once again.
If we are talking about workaround for libvirt bug, then it may make sense to introduce a simpler solution like denominator to force shares into smaller interval?

releasenotes/notes/remove-default-cputun.message:
Please note that live migration will remove the default value from the domain automatically. 

Btw, can this automatic default removal cause that a VM live migrated to a host will get significantly less CPU shares than it got on the source host? Unfortunately libvirt does not state what will be the default shares value if not provided in the domain. But if the libvirt default is lot less than the nova calculated default was, then I can see trouble. E.g:
* Have two hosts (A, B) each with two VMs, each VM with a 8 vCPUs, and no shares defined in the flavor so every VM is defaulted to 8 * 1024 shares on both hosts.
* Nova is upgraded with this patch
* One VM is now live migrated from host A to host B. On Host B there will be now 3 VMs. Two with 8*1024 shares as before and one with whatever the libvirt default will be. If that default is << 8 * 1024 then the migrated VM will be starved as far as I understand.

> This more and more looks like to me as a failure of libvirt to hide the underlying layer. So if Nova want to fix this well then Nova needs to check the host OS for default and adjust the values based on that. That sounds bad. :/

I think this is where Sean's idea to deprecate the current quota extra specs and provider something new with a higher level of abstraction comes in.

> To be constructive; can we not change the value during migration for a single VM but change it for every VM on a host at once? I assume these share values can be updated dynamically while the VM is running happily. So can we remove the values from every domains at nova-compute service startup?

We could, but that would be complementary to this patch, as we still need to not generate the broken XML with values > 10000 for future instances.

So, small note: based on my reading of the libvirt docs, there is no libvirt default, but rather an OS default: "If this is omitted, it defaults to the OS provided defaults" [1]

To answer the question, that's possible, but that isn't limited to live migration. In your case, if a VM on A gets rebooted, and the OS default is less than the Nova default, it will suddenly have less CPU shares than the other VMs. I'm not sure how we can avoid this...

[1] https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#cpu-tuning

> > This more and more looks like to me as a failure of libvirt to hide the underlying layer. So if Nova want to fix this well then Nova needs to check the host OS for default and adjust the values based on that. That sounds bad. :/
> 
> I think this is where Sean's idea to deprecate the current quota extra specs and provider something new with a higher level of abstraction comes in.
> 

That sounds good.

> > To be constructive; can we not change the value during migration for a single VM but change it for every VM on a host at once? I assume these share values can be updated dynamically while the VM is running happily. So can we remove the values from every domains at nova-compute service startup?
> 
> We could, but that would be complementary to this patch, as we still need to not generate the broken XML with values > 10000 for future instances.

I'm OK not to generate the default len(cpu) * 1024 value for new instances. 
What I'm questioning is if we:
a) want to remove that default value during live-migration of an instance and potentially put the instance in starvation on the destination
b) instead keep the value during migration, but remove the value at nova-compute startup. This way all the defaulted VM gets the value reset at the same time decreasing the chance of starvation.

marking this resolved

the starvation risk while possible i think is less problematic then requriing cold migration for rooling upgrade or other more disruptive workarounds where you are doing a host os upgrade.
this si now docuemented so i think this si safe to proceed wtih.

thanks gibi for raising that concern.

This more and more looks like to me as a failure of libvirt to hide the underlying layer. So if Nova want to fix this well then Nova needs to check the host OS for default and adjust the values based on that. That sounds bad. :/

To be constructive; can we not change the value during migration for a single VM but change it for every VM on a host at once? I assume these share values can be updated dynamically while the VM is running happily. So can we remove the values from every domains at nova-compute service startup?

Zuul CI's log zuul-info/inventory.yaml [1] shows that ansible-collections-openstack is not being installed from git. TripleO CI jobs such as periodic-tripleo-ci-centos-9-standalone-master still work because ansible-collections-openstack is installed as an rpm package later.

pls submit similar patch in downstream overrides

Oh right😱 Role os_tempest uses openstack.cloud.* modules although it does not list AOC in its requirements [1] 🙄 

A second patch [2] is required to prevent quickstart.sh from installing AOC at all. But then role os_tempest fails [3] because it does NOT use the AOC release that got installed from RDO RPMs even though the path to the RPM installed collection is in ansible.cfg [5] which is used in quickstart.sh [6].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/src/branch/master/requirements.yml
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/+/849620
[3] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/testproject/+/43963/3
[4] https://logserver.rdoproject.org/63/43963/3/check/periodic-tripleo-ci-centos-9-standalone-master/4da503f/job-output.txt
[5] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/src/branch/master/ansible.cfg#L19
[6] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/src/commit/b48d869e14de40444d69a107a0b718b5f721e912/quickstart.sh#L595

We need this patch and it works as expected [1]. When Ansible OpenStack collection (aoc) is in required-projects, then quickstart will install it from git (master branch) [2]. This is not what we want in TripleO jobs (only in tripleo jobs we use in aoc itself), there we want to use a known working release of aoc which is 1.8.0 atm. When aoc is not in required-projects, then it will be installed via ansible-collection-requirements.yml [3]. My other patch [4] changes this ansible-collection-requirements.yml to use aoc 1.8.0 in TripleO jobs.

Both changes, this one and [4] are required. Once we merge both, changes in master branch of aoc will not break TripleO.

[1] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/c/testproject/+/43963/3
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/src/commit/b48d869e14de40444d69a107a0b718b5f721e912/quickstart.sh#L123

Dockerfile.message:
The default configuration is to start as root and drop priveleges, so that it can get port 79.

If a user wants to avoid that, they can do so by specifying some config options.

We also might be able to do something with caps to avoid it.

But at least for now, this still gets us to a point where all the zuul processes run as non-root in the default configuration without any special configuration from operators.
zuul-fingergw shouldn't need root, or does it?
It listens on port 79 by default so needs root to open that socket then it can drop privs.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I'm amazed I didn't add the 'functools.wraps' decorator *also* when I was doing it, since I'm pretty sure I added these somewhere else for exactly this reason. This is of course the correct thing to do. Note that many decorators in nova already had this decorator and I still added the '__signature__' line because it seemed necessary to allow me to compare e.g. the 'nova.db.api' and 'nova.db.sqlalchemy.api' functions, but I've since realized that was only necessary because the local tooling I'd written to do this inspect relied on 'inspect.getfullargspec' instead of 'inspect.signature'. The former does not respect the '__wrapped__' parameter [1] (nor does it offer any way to), while 'inspect.signature' [2] does by default.

All this is to say yes, this totally makes sense and we don't need the '__signature__' line.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/inspect.html#inspect.getfullargspec
[2] https://docs.python.org/3.5/library/inspect.html#inspect.signature

I have two concerns about this patch:

(1) It could be considered to set a precedent for other drivers to backport features.  The project team has not thought that is a good idea in the past, and I'm pretty sure we don't want to do it in general.  If we decide to allow this backport, we need to be very clear about why it's being allowed so that other vendors can set expectations accordingly.

(2) From one perspective, this looks like a low risk patch because it is a very small change and all the work is being done on the backend, but the thing to worry about is whether there are other changes present in branch W that support proper functioning; if these other changes aren't present in branch W-1, then we will be introducing a regression.  So we need to be careful, and it would be good to have some evidence documenting that this change won't introduce a problem.

Hirotaka

In previous commit log[1]. 

> The instance.addresses value will be a dictionary of network: [addr_info] key/value pairs.
> ...(snip)...
> The nova api changed quite a while ago so we need to catch up.

I think that was a wrong description because:
* We don't currently use nova api when initializing instance.addresses since the commit[2].
* instance.addresses is currently a list instance.

---
[1]: https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/0f666fb95f1909932fe635d8717e7ff66d7f7b44
[2]: https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/429c39890e3242c6a502037673943b38452c5811


Here is my short investigation:

`instance.addresses` is `SimpleInstance.addresses` property which returns `self.db_info.addresses`.

```
    @property
    def addresses(self):
        if hasattr(self.db_info, 'addresses'):
            return self.db_info.addresses
        else:
            return None
```
https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/src/branch/master/trove/instance/models.py#L229

SimpleInstance constructor initializes self.db_info which is passed by the second parameter.
```
    def __init__(self, context, db_info, datastore_status, root_password=None,
                 ds_version=None, ds=None, locality=None):
```
https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/src/branch/master/trove/instance/models.py#L199

db_info.address, which is currently a `list` instance, is initialized here in load_simple_instance_addresses:
```
    addresses = []
    user_ports = []
    client = clients.create_neutron_client(context, db_info.region_id)
    ports = neutron.get_instance_ports(client, db_info.compute_instance_id)
    for port in ports:
        if port['network_id'] not in CONF.management_networks:
            LOG.debug('Found user port %s for instance %s', port['id']n,
                      db_info.id)

            user_ports.append(port['id'])
            for ip in port['fixed_ips']:
                # TODO(lxkong): IPv6 is not supported
                if netutils.is_valid_ipv4(ip.get('ip_address')):
                    addresses.append(
                        {
                            'address': ip['ip_address'],
                            'type': 'private',
                            'network': port['network_id']
                        }
                    )

            fips = neutron.get_port_fips(client, port['id'])
            if len(fips) == 0:
                continue
            fip = fips[0]
            addresses.append(
                {'address': fip['floating_ip_address'], 'type': 'public'})

    db_info.ports = user_ports
    db_info.addresses = addresses
```
https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/src/branch/master/trove/instance/models.py#L142-L177
Hi, Hirotaka, thanks for your carefully review. this helps a lot.

tempest/api/object_storage/test_object_t.message:
If we *really* want to get fancy, we could see what algorithms are supported via swift's /info endpoint: https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/object-store/?expanded=list-activated-capabilities-detail#list-activated-capabilities

Response is a JSON dict; something like

 response.json()['tempurl'].get('allowed_digests', ['sha1'])

should get you the list to choose from and work with any Swift going back to 1.11.0.

OTOH, it's been like 5 years since Swift added support for sha256/sha512, and the stronger algorithms were enabled by default. Should be a pretty safe assumption that sha256 will be supported.
this would also help with using tempest against ceph/rgw which doesn't support sha256 (yet); will try that in a follow up patch

def _test_listener_create(self, protocol, protocol_port):

that calls
